title: Elihu’s Introduction
shortSummary: In Job 32, Elihu, a younger man, steps forward to speak after Job’s three friends cease their debate. He is angered both at Job for justifying himself rather than God and at the friends for failing to answer Job rightly. Elihu emphasizes that true wisdom comes from God’s Spirit, not merely from age or status.
timeline: Patriarchal Period, traditionally dated c. 2000-1800 BC

keyCharacters.name: Elihu
keyCharacters.description: A young man of the Buzite family who speaks up after Job’s three friends stop responding, offering a new perspective on the debate.

keyCharacters.name: Job
keyCharacters.description: The central figure of the book, a righteous man who has been suffering and is defending his innocence.

keyCharacters.name: Job’s Three Friends
keyCharacters.description: Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar, who have ceased to answer Job because they could not refute him.

definitions.definition: To be inflamed with strong emotion, especially anger or wrath.
A descendant of Buz, related to the tribe or clan from which Elihu comes.
The divine breath or inspiration from God that grants understanding and wisdom.
Words of praise or honor given insincerely to gain favor or avoid offense.

outline.heading: Silence of Job’s Friends and Elihu’s Anger
outline.description: Job’s three friends stop responding because they cannot refute him, which provokes Elihu’s anger both at Job for justifying himself and at the friends for their failure to answer.

outline.heading: Elihu’s Respect for Elders and His Decision to Speak
outline.description: Elihu explains his initial hesitation to speak out of respect for his elders but declares his intention to share his own opinion now that the older men have failed to provide answers.

outline.heading: Elihu’s Observation of the Debate
outline.description: Elihu recounts how he listened carefully to the arguments but found no convincing answer from Job’s friends, who eventually fell silent in amazement.

outline.heading: Elihu’s Urgent Desire to Speak
outline.description: Elihu expresses the pressure he feels within to speak, comparing it to wine ready to burst, and commits to speaking honestly without partiality or flattery.

application: Respect God’s timing and the wisdom of elders, but do not hesitate to speak truth when it is needed.
Seek the Spirit’s guidance for true understanding rather than relying solely on human wisdom or age.
Speak honestly and humbly, avoiding flattery or partiality in your words.
Recognize that God’s wisdom often comes through unexpected sources, including younger believers.

keyVerses.text: But there is a spirit in man: and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights that true wisdom and understanding come from God’s Spirit, not merely from human experience or age.

keyVerses.text: For I am full of matter, the spirit within me constraineth me.
keyVerses.significance: Elihu expresses the compelling inner drive to speak God’s truth, showing the urgency of sharing inspired wisdom.

keyVerses.text: Let me not, I pray you, accept any man's person, neither let me give flattering titles unto man.
keyVerses.significance: Elihu commits to impartiality and honesty, warning against favoritism and insincere praise in delivering God’s message.
